title: 115_hr1954
content: The "Servicemembers and Veterans Empowerment and Support Act of 2017" expands coverage by the Department of Veterans Affairs for counseling and treatment of sexual trauma, including cyber harassment of a sexual nature. It also adjusts the standard of proof for service-connection of mental health conditions related to military sexual trauma. The "Servicemembers and Veterans Empowerment and Support Act of 2017" adjusts the standard of proof for service-connection of mental health conditions related to military sexual trauma. The Secretary shall accept a diagnosis of a mental health condition by a professional, along with evidence of trauma, as proof of service-connection for veterans. The "Servicemembers and Veterans Empowerment and Support Act of 2017" adjusts the standard of proof for service-connection of mental health conditions related to military sexual trauma. Covered mental health conditions include post-traumatic stress disorder, anxiety, depression, or other diagnoses related to military sexual trauma. The Secretary may rebut service-connection with clear and convincing evidence. Reasons for granting or denying service-connection must be fully recorded. Military sexual trauma is defined as physical assault, battery, cyber harassment, or sexual acts. The "Servicemembers and Veterans Empowerment and Support Act of 2017" adjusts the standard of proof for service-connection of mental health conditions related to military sexual trauma, including post-traumatic stress disorder, anxiety, and depression. The Act defines military sexual trauma as physical assault, battery, cyber harassment, or sexual acts during active military service. The Secretary must consider evidence from nonmilitary sources for claims involving military sexual trauma. The Act adjusts the standard of proof for service-connection of mental health conditions related to military sexual trauma. Evidence from nonmilitary sources can corroborate the veteran's account of assault, battery, or harassment. Examples of corroborating evidence include records from various sources and statements from family members or healthcare providers. The Secretary must consider behavior changes as relevant evidence following an assault, battery, or harassment. Examples of behavior changes that may indicate assault, battery, or harassment include requesting a transfer, decreased work performance, substance abuse, mental health issues, and unexplained changes in behavior. The Secretary must inform veterans of the evidence required for compensation for post-traumatic stress disorder related to military sexual trauma. The Secretary must inform veterans of the evidence required for compensation related to assault, battery, or harassment. Veterans are advised to provide corroborating evidence and sources, which will be reviewed by medical professionals to determine if the incident occurred. The Secretary will ensure a point of contact for veterans in need of assistance. The Secretary will provide veterans with contact information for assistance related to compensation claims. Annual reports on claims for disabilities incurred or aggravated by military sexual trauma are required by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. These reports must be submitted to Congress annually, starting from March 1, 2018, to track the consistency of decisions across regional offices. The reports will include the number of covered claims submitted and considered during each fiscal year. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit annual reports to Congress on claims for disabilities related to military sexual trauma. The reports will detail the number and percentage of approved and denied claims, disaggregated by sex, as well as the reasons for denial. The annual reports to Congress on claims for disabilities related to military sexual trauma must include the three most common reasons for denials, the number of denials based on failure to report for a medical examination, pending claims, average processing time, and training provided to Veterans Benefits Administration employees on covered claims. The section defines "covered claims" as claims for disability compensation related to military sexual trauma. It also includes definitions for "covered mental health condition" and "military sexual trauma" as per section 1154(c)(3) of the title. Annual reports on claims for disabilities related to military sexual trauma will be required. The effective date for this provision is specified in section 1154 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, information for members of the armed forces regarding services at Vet Centers is also addressed. The Secretary of Defense must inform Armed Forces members about their eligibility for services at Vet Centers. Sexual Assault Response Coordinators must also inform members reporting military sexual trauma about Vet Center services. Definitions for military sexual trauma and Vet Centers are provided.
